November 2, 2014: Fiction
LEAVING TIME, by Jodi Picoult. (Ballantine.) After searching for her mother, who
has disappeared, for more than 10 years, a woman employs a psychic and a
detective.
DEADLINE, by John Sandford. (Putnam.) Dognappers and a murdered reporter
draw the attention of the Minnesota investigator Virgil Flowers.
EDGE OF ETERNITY, by Ken Follett. (Dutton.) Five interrelated families grapple
with the events of the 1960s through the 1980s; Book 3 of the Century Trilogy.
BURN, by James Patterson and Michael Ledwidge. (Little, Brown.) Detective
Michael Bennett, back in New York City, investigates a peculiar crime in Harlem.
SOMEWHERE SAFE WITH SOMEBODY GOOD, by Jan Karon. (Putnam.) The
Mitford character Father Tim finds friends and family wrestling with difficulties.
LILA, by Marilynne Robinson. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux.) The difficult early life of
the woman who becomes the wife of the widower and minister John Ames; a back
story to "Gilead."
ALL THE LIGHT WE CANNOT SEE, by Anthony Doerr. (Scribner.) The lives of a
blind French girl and a gadget-obsessed German boy before and during World
War II.
PERSONAL, by Lee Child. (Delacorte.) Jack Reacher, a former military cop, helps
the State Department and the C.I.A. stop a sniper who has targeted a G8 summit.
SOME LUCK, by Jane Smiley. (Knopf.) The lives of an Iowa farm family between
1920 and 1953; the first volume of a trilogy.
THE NARROW ROAD TO THE DEEP NORTH, by Richard Flanagan. (Knopf.)
The hero of the Man Booker Prize-winning novel about love, good and evil is a
P.O.W. working on the Thai-Burma Death Railway during World War II.
WINTER STREET, by Elin Hilderbrand. (Little, Brown.) Complications ensue when
the owner of Nantucket’s Winter Street Inn gathers his four children and their
families for Christmas.
MR. MIRACLE, by Debbie Macomber. (Ballantine.) A young woman returns home
for the holidays, and with the help of a guardian angel finds love with the boy next
door.
THE GOLDFINCH, by Donna Tartt. (Little, Brown.)  A painting becomes a boy’s
prize, guilt and burden.
NORA WEBSTER, by Colm Toibin. (Scribner.) In the 1970s, an Irish widow
struggles to find her identity.
November 2, 2014
Non-Fiction
KILLING PATTON, by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard. (Holt.) The host of “The O’Reilly
Factor” recounts the death of Gen. George S. Patton in December 1945.
NOT THAT KIND OF GIRL, by Lena Dunham. (Random House.) A collection of
revealing and often humorous personal essays from the creator and star of “Girls.”
AS YOU WISH, by Cary Elwes with Joe Layden. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster.) The
making of the movie “The Princess Bride,” 25 years ago.
BEING MORTAL, by Atul Gawande. (Metropolitan/ Holt.) The surgeon and New Yorker
writer considers how doctors fail patients at the end of life, and how they can do better.
THE INNOVATORS, by Walter Isaacson. (Simon & Schuster.) Studies of the people
who created computers and the Internet, beginning in the 1840s.
NEIL PATRICK HARRIS: CHOOSE YOUR OWN AUTOBIOGRAPHY, by Neil Patrick
Harris with David Javerbaum. (Crown Archetype.) The actor’s life story is structured as
a Choose Your Own Adventure book.
WORTHY FIGHTS, by Leon Panetta with Jim Newton. (Penguin Press.) The writer's
experience in the Obama administration as director of the C.I.A. and secretary of
defense.
WHAT IF?, by Randall Munroe. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt.) Scientific (but often
humorous) answers to hypothetical questions, based in part on the author’s website,
xkcd.com.
STOP THE COMING CIVIL WAR, by Michael Savage. (Center Street.) The radio host
urges true patriots to save the country from the machinations of the left.
ROCKS, by Joe Perry with David Ritz. (Simon & Schuster.) A memoir by the Aerosmith
guitarist and songwriter.
I AM MALALA, by Malala Yousafzai with Christina Lamb. (Little, Brown.) The
experience of the young Pakistani advocate for women’s education shot by the
Taliban.
JESUS ON TRIAL, by David Limbaugh. (Regnery.) The lawyer and political
commentator uses his legal training to evaluate, and affirm, the truthfulness of the
Bible.
13 HOURS, by Mitchell Zuckoff with members of the Annex Security Team. (Twelve.)
Six C.I.A. contract employees discuss their experience during the attack on the State
Department compound in Benghazi, Libya, in 2012.
HOW WE GOT TO NOW, by Steven Johnson. (Riverhead.) A history of innovation
focused on the development of six key technologies of modern life; the companion
